Award.AwardTitle: Structures and Densities of Silicate Liquids Under High Pressure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. This proposal requests funds to support experimental studies of (1) structures of silicate liquids at high pressures, and (2) the pressure-volume-temperature (P-V-T) relations of silicate and magmatic liquids using new synchrotron x-ray diffraction and absorption methods. An x-ray scattering technique will be utilized to determine structures of liquid materials in diamond anvil cells (DAC) under a wide range of pressures up to the core mantle boundary. A newly developed x-ray absorption method will be used to measure densities of silicate liquids at high pressure-temperature conditions. To reach the required high temperatures for melting refractory silicates, a double sided laser heated DAC technique and a recently developed internally heated DAC technique are used in combination with synchrotron x-ray beams to analyze the liquid structures. An externally heated DAC and the Paris-Edinburgh cell will be used for liquid density measurements. These experiments will provide structures and densities of silicate glasses, germanate and silicate liquids, and magmatic liquids at high pressures and high temperatures. Particular effort will be put on the local structural change, including the change in coordination number, in liquids with increasing pressures. The compression behavior of both tetrahedral liquids and octahedral liquids will be determined in their stability fields. These results will provide crucial data on liquid-crystal density inversions and set constraints on differentiation and dynamic models in plausible magma oceans in planetary history. The proposed research will also provide experimental evidence for understanding the possible presence of melts in the low and ultra-low velocity zones at the bottom regions of the Earth's upper mantle and the lower mantle.


Broader Impacts. This proposal supports a post-doctoral associate who will play a major role in carrying out the research activities. The PI of this proposal is a beamline scientist, with the opportunity of working with a large number of graduate students, post-doctoral scientists, and senior scientists from all over the world. The experience and technical solutions from the proposed challenging experiments are useful for outside users in performing their own. The results of the proposed research will be reported in various meetings and published in scientific journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant has supported experimental studies of (1) structures of germinate and silicate glasses and liquids at high pressures, and (2) the links between the structural data and several macroscopic properties such as density, elasticity, and viscosity. We have developed two types of high pressure devices suitable for studying this class of amorphous materials. These new tools have been integrated with synchrotron radiations at beam-lines of the Advanced Photon Source (APS), near Chicago. The conventional diamond anvil cell technique has been modified for applying x-ray diffraction technique for structural studies of amorphous materials (glasses and liquids) which require a large coverage in reciprocal space and a low background signal from anvil materials. A new Paris-Edinburgh cell, capable of generating high pressures to more than 10 gigapascals and high temperatures to over 2500 K, was successfully installed at the sector 16 beamline at the APS. This development has led to an establishment of an infrastructure project funded by COMPRES (Consortium for Materials Properties Research in Earth Sciences, funded by NSF), which has opened a new capability in the U.S. for comprehensive studies of silicate liquids at high pressures and high temperatures, including microscopic structure and macroscopic properties such as density, sound velocity, thermal conductivity, and viscosity.

Science highlight 1: Helium makes the silica glass less compressible 

The solubility of rare gases in the silicate melt at high pressure is of importance for understanding the early history of the Earth and planetary degassing. Recently, several works indicate that the noble gas solubility in the silicate melt is mainly controlled by changes in liquid structure. Above certain threshold pressures, there are clear discontinuous drops of noble gas solubility (He, Ne, Ar ...) in the silicate melt.  In our study, we observed that the dissolved helium in a silica glass can have a strong effect on the glass structure evolution with pressure, stabilizing the intermediate range order structure at considerably expanded pressure range. Thus the high helium solubility may be sustainable at very high pressures (to the middle of the lower mantle pressures). This observation will change our views on noble gas partitioning during solidification of the magma ocean, which in turn will change the evolution model due to the strong effect on the compressibility.

Science highlight 2: Structure and viscosity

The silicate melts along the diopside-jadeite join display different degrees of polymerization. The in-situ structure measurements reveal different pressure dependences in melts along the diopside-jadeite join, in correlation with the degree of polymerization. While polymerized melts (such as jadeite) generally possess negative pressure dependences in viscosity, the pressure dependence of viscosity in depolymerized melt (such as diopside) is positive. Our results provide microscopic structural information and can be used to compare the pressure dependence of intermediate-order network structure with the degree of polymerization. We have demonstrated a clear correlation between the pressure-induced structural change and the viscosity of the silicate melts.

Science highlight 3: Structure and sound velocity

The first simultaneous structure and elastic wave velocity measurement for silica glass at the pressure conditions to 6.8 gigapascals at ~500 °C indicates a strong correlation between the intermediate range order structure and the compressional velocity (Vp) or Poisson’s ratio. However, such correlation was not found for shear velocity (Vs).
